newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian villagers hope poll brings better life.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian villagers hope poll brings better life.

text.p: Young Bulgarians in the run-down village of Jivkovo hope Saturday's parliamentary elections will propel reforms to help them start private businesses and end poverty and joblessness.
"I dream of setting up a family farm, but I have no cash. The only possible sponsors now are the local mafiosos who will not let me run the farm properly," 30-year-old Kiril Penov told Reuters.
"There is lots of money in farming if managed properly. I know how," said Penov, who has a university degree in animal breeding but now works as a bus dispatcher.

A tiny village on the plains 50 km (30 miles) south of Sofia, Jivkovo has a population of 600. As in most of the country's rural communities, most of the residents are old and the local economy stagnant.
"If we could be certain that we would not be racketeered and there was a functioning bank lending at affordable rates, we would start the business immediately," said Penov's wife Maria.
Curbing organised crime and corruption are the priorities of the Union of Democratic Forces (UDF), the favourites to win the election race.

The UDF hopes to capitalise on the support it won from month-long protests which toppled the former Socialist government in February, and the main question is how big their parliamentary majority will be.

An interim cabinet led by Sofia's UDF mayor Stefan Sofianski has run the country since February, sealing a deal with the International Monetary Fund and kicking off the reform process the new government must continue.
The interior minister has launched a high-profile campaign against organised crime, which has soared unchecked since the end of communist rule, helped by an inadequate legal system.
The only consolation for those in the impoverished countryside is that for some in the cities, things are even worse.
"If it was not for my dozen sheep and the vegetables I grow, our son and daughter in the city would starve," said Tsvetana Milcheva, who formerly worked at nearby factory.
Many urban families rely on relatives in the countryside for cheap food supplies.

Wages have been drastically eroded by a shattering economic crisis. The lev equivalent of $100 at end-1995 now is worth a mere $30 -- about the average state monthly salary, yet hardly enough to pay electricity and heating bills.
Delayed reforms and corruption have led to the closures of a chain of banks and a drastic slump in the lev currency.
"Everything is enormously expensive, bus and train tickets. Half of my pension goes for a visit to the doctor and the rest on medicines," said Stoyanka Ilkova, a retired worker from a nearby factory.
But gloom is beginning to disperse for Sasho Neikov, who works in the nearby Ihtiman smelting plant, which was recently bought out by its 800 workers.
"We have clients in Italy and Germany, we have had some difficulties. We have kept the average wage at around $80 and hope to do better," said Neikov.
Communist ideas have not been abandoned by everyone. Jivkovo's 96-year-old blacksmith Ivan Nachev said he would back the tiny Bulgarian Communist Party.
"My father was a communist. I was a communist since early childhood and I will remain one," said the sprightly Nachev.
After the collapse of one-party rule in 1989, most former communists resurfaced in the Bulgarian Socialist Party, which won a clear majority in the 1994 general election.
The communists, who still use the hammer and sickle symbol, are expected to poll well below the four percent threshold needed to enter parliament.
